dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cafeteria in a quiet airport in the provinces. Few pass A single woman in her mid-40s (JULIETTE) sits at a table. coffee. Gazes around her as if discovering something new often has an expression of eager surprise, as if seeing t people, places for the first time ever. She seems uncomfortable in the clothes she is wearing. At is an old-fashioned suitcase. A younger woman (LEA, early 30s) appears behind Juliette. a meter away. Juliette hasn’t noticed her. Clearly deeply moved, Léa qu observes her for a few seconds. Then, sensing a presence, Juliette looks round. Léa leans forward and hugs her tight before Juliette has react. Juliette is slightly taken aback. She doesn’t return the hug at first. Then awkwardly puts round Léa. 2. INT. LEA’S CAR - DAY Léa is driving. Next to her, Juliette tugs at the sleeves of her sweater.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Is it too big?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: I like that sweater. The skirt, too. I often wear them. Juliette doesn’t reply.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: I thought it would be better to wait until you arrived to go shopping for clothes. Léa glances at Juliette. Beat. There’s something out of place about Juliette. She even s in the car seat, as if unused to it.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Did you have a good trip?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: I don’t like flying. Léa glances at her again.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Have you lived here long?

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Ten years. I finished my PhD here, met Luc, got married, was offered the job... The usual stuff. Juliette is silent. The CAMERA lingers on her face. 3. INT. LEA’S HOUSE - DAY Léa shows Juliette into the house.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Welcome to our kingdom! The kitchen’s over there with the living room opposite, our home offices and a library at the far end. Upstairs, there’s just bedrooms. Do you want to see yours? Juliette replies by a slight nod and the flicker of a smi Léa leads the way up the stairs. On the first landing, she shows Juliette into a room.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Will it be okay?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: That little door leads to your private bathroom. (glances at her watch) Yikes, I have to pick up the girls! I’1l be back in half an hour. Will you be okay on your own? Juliette nods. Léa hurries out. On the landing, she stops in her tracks. Slowly retraces her step, looks at Juliette and says in a tone:

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: I’m glad you’re here. Léa gives Juliette a kiss on the cheek and goes. Juliette is expressionless. OS, feet dashing down the stairs. The jangle of keys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take a look round the house, if you want ! The front door thunks closed. Juliette hasn’t moved an inch. She remains motionless like that for a long Moment. 4. INT. LEA’S HOUSE - DAY MONTAGE of Juliette’s tour of the house. In the living room, she strokes a cat dozing on a chair. In a study, she runs her hand over the back of a couch. G framed photos. In the kitchen, she pours herself a glass of water. Drink leaning back against the fridge. Upstairs, Juliette opens a door. A child’s bedroom. She c door hurriedly. She opens another door. A library full of books. With a s and two chairs. Sitting in one of the chairs, an elderly reading.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, I... I didn’t think anyone was home. The old man looks up without a word and smiles at her.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: I... My name’s Juliette. I’m Léa’s sister. Still not a word. Just a kindly smile.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Like I said, I’m very sorry. Smiling, the old man goes back to his book, as if indiffe her presence. 5. EXT/INT. LEA’S HOUSE - DAY Léa closes the back door of the car. She has a two-year-o (EMELIA) in her arms. Another little girl, (CLELIS, known as Little Lili) waits sidewalk. She looks 8-9 years old. Both girls are Asian.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Lili, open the gate, will you? You know it’s hard when I’m carrying Emelia. They go through the gate into the small front garden.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: Is Auntie Juliette going to stay with us forever?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sweetheart, just some time. Be nice to her, okay? She’s tired. Don’t pester her. They enter the house.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Juliette? It’s us! Juliette comes down the stairs. The kids gaze up at her. As soon as she reaches the bottom step, Lili rushes over.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: Hello, Auntie! Juliette seems quite distant, or maybe just ill at ease. Lili stands on tiptoes to give her a kiss. Juliette hesitates fractionally before giving her a kiss Emelia gurgles the word “Auntie” repeatedly.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: These are my two princesses, Clélis - but everybody calls her Little Lili - and little miss Emelia. Give Juliette a nice smile, sweety!

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: Auntie, come and see my bedroom!

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Don’t start! Go straight into the kitchen. There’s milk and biscuits on the table. Chop, chop. The two girls run off into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Did you look round the house?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Yes, I... I went into the library. There was an old man...

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Of course, silly me, I should have warned you. That’s Luc’s father.

dialogues.speaker: LILI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (yells) Papy Paul! His brain’s gone all mushy and he lost his tongue!

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Lili! He had a bad stroke three years ago. He hasn’t spoken a word since. He  spends all day reading. You’1l see, he’s a lovely man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dinner time. The whole family is round the table: Léa, th girls, Juliette, Papy Paul - smiling dumbly - and Luc, Lé husband, also in his early-mid 30s. The two young girls are very excited. Léa makes a big effort to seem relaxed. Juliette still seems a little strange, as if everything i her. And Luc just seems a bit uptight. Luc Have you ever been to the Lorraine region before?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: No, this is the first time. Luc Everybody thinks it’s just like being in Germany, that it’s freezing cold all the time...

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: It is! Luc Not all the time.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Just eat your dinner!

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Were you born here? Luc Yes, but my Dad comes from Poland. He arrived after the war. Isn’t that right, Dad? The old man merely smiles a little more insistently than

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Luc’s Mum was Russian. He married a girl who’s half-French, half-English. And our two daughters are Viet. It’s all the colors of Benetton in this house.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: You’ve lost your accent, Mummy, but Auntie Juliette still has one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, she grew up in England. Luc Anybody see the water jug?

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Katrina broke it and I haven’t had time to buy another. (to Juliette) Katrina’s the cleaner. She comes every Thursday. Hide anything fragile. She’s always breaking things. That’s why we call her Katrina. Because she leaves a trail of devastation behind her! Her real name’s Marie-Paule.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: (to Luc) Léa said you do research at the university?

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: (jokily) You two sound like we’re at a party full of strangers.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: Daddy’s a lexicolographer. Luc Lexicographer’s good enough for me. Our unit is working on an interactive, intuitive dictionary that can be reactivated in real time.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: It’s you guys that need to reactivate. In seven years, they’ve only got to ‘C’. Even the Académie Frangaise goes faster than that. Luc There’s no comparison. That reminds me, there was a message on the machine from one of your students, a guy called Bamaké or Bakamé, something like that. A problem with his marks, I think.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Bamakalé? I don’t believe it! He won’t give up.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: Why didn’t we ever meet you before, Auntie? Everyone falls silent. Juliette doesn’t know what to say. Luc glances anxiously The two girls don’t seem to notice. Papy Paul keeps on ea smiling away.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: I was... away. For a very long time. Léa changes the subject. A little too quickly. She hands Juliette a dish.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Do you want some more?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: No, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Don’t you like it?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: It’s very good, but...

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: Where were you away? Luc (snaps) Is this some kind of interrogation! Leave your aunt in peace! Eat! 7. INT. LEA & LUC’S BEDROOM - NIGHT Léa and Luc are ready for bed. Luc How long does she plan on staying?

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: How should I know? As long as she needs. A few weeks, a few months... Is it a problem? Luc To be honest, yes. Okay, she’s your sister, but...

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: But what? Luc You heard Lili. She wanted to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So? Luc Her being “away” won’t work for long.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: It’1l work as long as it works, we’1l see. Luc “We’1l see! We’ll see!” You make me laugh. What are you going to say to her? The truth?

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Luc, don’t give me a hard time. This is our first evening. I’ve just got my sister back. I don’t know if you realize what that means. I’ve just got her back. Luc You hardly know her. Just because you went to see her a couple of times for a few hours in the last few months doesn’t... You were only a teenager when she -

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Be quiet! Luc Okay, I’1l be quiet. Quiet as a mouse. (beat ) But think of us a little, too. 8. INT. JULIETTE’S BEDROOM - NIGHT Juliette stands by the window. We can vaguely make out th below. Juliette is still wearing Léa’s clothes Léa. She goes ove bed. Sits on the edge, as if she plans to spend the whole like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s total, happy, bubbly chaos in the kitchen. The girls are finishing their breakfast. Léa is a whirl o activity. Still in his pyjamas, Papy Paul slurps coffee from a bowl as_ always. Juliette observes the scene, leaning against the wall wit tea in one hand. 10

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C’mon, kids! Chop, chop, we’re gonna be late!

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: Aren’t we always?

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Emelia, what are you doing? What are you doing? I don’t believe it! Emelia has smeared yoghurt all over her dress.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: I’1l have to change your dress now. Lili, finish up quickly. Léa dashes out with Emelia in her arms. Papy Paul leaves also. Juliette and Little Lili are alone.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: Don’t you eat breakfast?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: It depends.

dialogues.speaker: LILT
dialogues.text: I’m never hungry in the morning. Ever since I was a little girl. Mummy gets so angry! Did you ever see me when I was little, when Mummy and Daddy brought me back from Vietnam?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: I don’t believe you. Your nose is getting longer. (beat ) Daddy! Luc has just entered. Little Lili throws her arms round h Luc (awkwardly) Morning, Juliette. Did you sleep well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Léa and Little Lili get out of the car and join the flow and children. Léa turns and leans towards the passenger side window.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: You’re not coming? 11

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I’1l1 wait here.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: ‘Bye, Auntie! Juliette looks overwhelmed by it all. She doesn’t answer. Little Lili and Léa walk toward the gates.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: I put some more canteen tickets in your bag.

dialogues.speaker: LILT
dialogues.text: I noticed.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Your gym stuff is in there, too. Try not to lose anything this time.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: Mummy?

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: Auntie’s a bit weird, isn’t she?

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: What makes you say that?

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: I don’t know. She doesn’t say much.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Give her time to adapt, eh? Go on, go! A kiss and Little Lili walks into school.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Ask Madame Rouyer if she found your pink beret! 11, INT. LEA’S CAR - DAY Juliette is in the passenger seat. Léa’s face looms up at the window. Juliette stares straight ahead, breathing heavily. Léa walks round and gets in behind the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Are you okay? Juliette nods several times, her breath rasping slightly. 12

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Yes. Léa pulls out and drives in silence for a moment. Beat. Juliette shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: The police station is close to the university. I’m teaching for two hours, but we can meet up after, if you want? There’s a nice café just opposite the campus gates.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: You know what they want to see you for?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: I have to sign in at regular times.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Didn’t you ever see anyone? I mean, did anyone come to see you?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: The visitors.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: (beat ) Do you hate me?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: For never coming to see you.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: I wrote at first.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: I never received any letters.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: One evening, Dad saw me. Mummy and him gave me a real roasting. They banned me from writing. They said you... you 13  didn’t exist. I was a kid then you know.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: I meant to tell you...

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: It was the social services who came up with the idea to call you just before I got out, not me.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: I’m glad they did. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: I’m glad they did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliette sits on a bench with an OLD LADY beside her. The old lady glances at Juliette. Smiles. Juliette smiles Beat. The old lady glances at her again.

dialogues.speaker: OLD LADY
dialogues.text: Are you reporting a crime, too?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: No. Just then, an INSPECTOR appears. Plain clothes, same age Juliette.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Juliette Fontaine?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Follow me, please. 13. INT. INSPECTOR’S OFFICE - DAY Juliette sits opposite the Inspector He flicks through a file, pores over a couple of pages, g few pages and re-reads, frowning, but not hostile or judg friendly almost. He closes the file.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: 14  I see you’re a doctor.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Was. I was struck off the medical register.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Makes no difference. Once a doctor always a doctor. It’s like me. I’11 always be a cop. (suddenly) You have a pretty name. I don’t like my name, but Fontaine is very pretty. It brings to mind gurgling water streams, rivers... The Orinoco. You know the Orinoco? No? He uses his pen to point to a poster on the wall behind h shows a broad swathe of an unidentifiable river.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: There’1l1 be no more fountains soon. Municipalities are closing them down - even in tiny villages. They’re filled with earth and made into flower beds. Stupid geraniums, usually. (switches topic again) I won’t hassle you. The law says we have to see each other, so we see each other, but I won’t give you any bother. Do you have a job?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Not yet.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: A place to stay.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: With my sister.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: That’s nice. Family’s important. You’re lucky. I live alone. Divorced. Small apartment. Small bed. Anyway, you don’t want to hear all that. He gets up, goes to the door.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: See you in two weeks?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Goodbye. 15

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. UNIVERSITY CAMPUS
dialogues.text: Léa walks down a hallway. Groups of students hang out, sh breeze. Léa nods to a colleague going the other way. She enters t room, checks through the mail in her box, throws some stu She opens and scans one letter. Then another that makes her roll her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Not him again! He’s a real pain! Another colleague (MICHEL) approaches and whispers into L

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: One of your many lovers writing to you? Léa doesn’t look round, just keeps reading.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: If only! Bamakalé!

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: Ah ha! Prosper Napoleon Bamakalé, descendant of ancient Togolese royalty, son of a prince of royal blood, repeating his first year for the third time.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: I’m getting fond of him, actually. I keep telling him it’s not a mistake, but he doesn’t get it.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: Tell me about it! I had him all last year. Are you off?

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: I’m done for the day.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: I’11 walk you to your car. They step outside without a break in their conver sation.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: Have you finished marking your mid - terms?

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Almost. I have ten or so left to do.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: 16  Lucky you! I haven’t even started. Every time I look at the pile on my desk, I feel so exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Get a move on though, the Dean wants all the marks in by the 18".

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: The Dean! (changes subject) What did you decide for that conference I told you about?

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: We’1l see. Léa sees Juliette waiting by the car.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: You’re already here? I thought we were meeting in the café.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: It didn’t take very long.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Michel, this is Juliette, my sister. Juliette, this is Michel, a colleague.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: Hello... (to Léa) You never told me you had a sister and a very pretty one at that.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Don’t listen to him. Michel’s a specialist on love letters from the 16" century to the present day. And it rubs off on him. (to Michel) Friday of next week, are you free?

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: why?

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Dinner at our house, with Samir and Kaisha.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: I should be able to make it. Can I let you know next week?

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: 17  Sure. Don’t forget your marking.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Juliette.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: C’mon, let’s go shopping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliette and Léa are sitting at a table with a cup of tea a plate of cakes. On the chair next to them and at their feet are shopping various stores.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Good?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: (nods) You remember Bouchard’s in Rouen?

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: It was a bit like this. I used to take you there on a Wednesday after your ballet lesson.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: With Old Mother Stabush?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Fat Old Mother Stabush!

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: She couldn’t even do points anymore. I remember she had a moustache, too. We were all scared of her.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: I was at uni and I always picked you up and took you to Bouchard’s. You had a cream puff every time.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: (tremulously) I don’t remember.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: 18  You were only seven or eight. There were always stacks of old ladies in there...

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: (like it’s a real drama) Why don’t I remember?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: You sat there so proud. A proper little lady with your cream cake.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: (tears up) I don’t even remember it. Juliette suddenly realizes that Léa is distraught.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Don’t worry, you were only little. 16. INT. LITTLE LILI’S BEDROOM - EVENING The door opens. Little Lili and Juliette enter the bedroom, followed by E

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: (to Emelia) No, you’re not coming in! Out! It’s my room! You can show her yours later. (closes the door) Kid sisters are so annoying! Was Mummy like that when she was little?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: She wasn’t too bad.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: Is she your real sister?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: You’re Granny Lizbeth’s daughter, too?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: That’s right.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: Okay, this is the doll graveyard. She opens a suitcase filled with a dozen dolls.

dialogues.speaker: LILT
dialogues.text: I don’t like dolls, so when someone gives me one, I bury it in here right 19  away. That’s my computer. I watch DVDs on it mostly and type up my schoolwork. That’s what I made for Mother’s Day, but Katrina broke it. She says it wasn’t her, but she’s a liar! Those are my books...

dialogues.speaker: LEA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Dinner time!

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Do you read a lot? Juliette runs her fingers along the spines of the books. over one she apparently remembers from her childhood, cal Little Ladies.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: Less than Papy Paul, but quite a lot yes. This is my secret diary - well, it’s not so secret seeing as I leave it out and everybody can read it. I write poems in it. Do you want me to read you one?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: (recoils) No.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: Please, Auntie! Just a little one.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: (snaps) No. I said no! Little Lili looks at her in amazement. Juliette scurries out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliette is with a plump, smiling young woman ( the SOCIA They each sit on a couch facing each other across a coffe

dialogues.speaker: SOCIAL WORKER
dialogues.text: You’re lucky to have your sister, her family and a home.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: So I’ve been told.

dialogues.speaker: SOCIAL WORKER
dialogues.text: It’s true, though. Most people, when they get out, don’t know where to go. Nobody wants them. Their spouses almost always file for divorce. 20

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got that out of the way before I went in.

dialogues.speaker: SOCIAL WORKER
dialogues.text: Yes, it’s in your file. Right, well, the courses you did at Centrale will be very useful. People always need secretaries. Are your IT skills up to speed?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: I did all the updates whenever I got the chance.

dialogues.speaker: SOCIAL WORKER
dialogues.text: That’s good. I got you an interview at this company... (hands Juliette a card) They’re looking for someone. You have an appointment with a Monsieur Dupuis. We’1l be meeting regularly, but if you have any questions or anything, don’t hesitate to call me at the office...

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: SOCIAL WORKER
dialogues.text: I have to go now. You have people you can talk to, and there’s only two of us in the department. (beat ) I like the house. They get up. Juliette walks her to the door. They say goo Outside, Léa parks her car and gets out. She meets the So Worker by the gate. They nod. Léa enters.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Was that the social worker?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: She seems sweet enough.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: People whose role is to rummage through your life often seem sweet enough. Léa glances curiously at her sister. Puts her bag down. T 21

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess you’re right. We had that, too - Luc and me - when we adopted. Visits for this, visits for that, social workers, shrinks, and even an idiot doctor who had Luc walking up and down in his underpants in his office with his arms stretched out! I thought Luc was going to strangle him. He really resented all the questions and prying... Tea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Léa is making tea. Juliette stands close by.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: It took nearly two years for Little Lili and a bit less for Emelia. The first time we spent three months in Vietnam. We fell in love with the place and would have happily stayed longer. We had Little Lili with us almost the whole time, at the hotel, but the bureaucracy and all the formalities took forever.

dialogues.speaker: KATRINA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Léa?

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Yes, Marie-Paule?

dialogues.speaker: KATRINA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Shall I do the crystal, too?

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: No, don’t worry, leave it! I’1l do it! Do the cupboard doors, will you?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: How old was Little Lili?

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Two. But she looked half that.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: You met her mother?

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: No. But I have her address if ever she wants to contact her. That was very important for us. We didn’t want her to run into a brick wall later if she tried to find her. Emelia, on the other hand... Well, we got absolutely no information. She’1l never know... 22

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How old was she?

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: She was tiny! Barely three weeks old. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Was it Luc or you who couldn’t have kids?

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Neither of us. We’re both fertile. (beat ) I didn’t want a child of my own.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Because of me? No answer.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Because of what I did? Beat.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: I never tried to work out why. 19. INT. DUPUIS’ OFFICE - DAY MONSIEUR DUPUIS, early 50s, smug, sits behind his desk, t the phone. Juliette sits opposite him.

dialogues.speaker: DUPUIS
dialogues.text: Yes, well... So what?... That’s not my problem. We pay you to deliver our order, so you deliver it, period! Goodbye! He hangs up. Gazes at Juliette.

dialogues.speaker: DUPUIS
dialogues.text: Right, where were we... I won’t beat around the bush. I’m not a charity. I want skilled, hard-working staff. The rest is not my problem. Mrs... what’s her name again? Balboukian?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: That’s right.

dialogues.speaker: DUPUIS
dialogues.text: . said that you are up to speed with Excel, DTP and the whole shebang. Right? 23

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I passed all the tests.

dialogues.speaker: DUPUIS
dialogues.text: And you speak English?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: And Spanish.

dialogues.speaker: DUPUIS
dialogues.text: I don’t give a shit about Spanish but we have a lot of clients across the Channel. There’s stacks of stuff that needs translating... How long were you in jail?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Fifteen years.

dialogues.speaker: DUPUIS
dialogues.text: (whistles) Jeez! You knock off the President or something? No answer.

dialogues.speaker: DUPUIS
dialogues.text: What did you do? Still no answer.

dialogues.speaker: DUPUIS
dialogues.text: I want to know. What did you do to get so long? Kill someone? Did you?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: DUPUIS
dialogues.text: Who? Your husband? Lover? Another woman? No answer.

dialogues.speaker: DUPUIS
dialogues.text: I’m talking to you. Who did you kill?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: My son. My six-year-old son. The blood seeps out of Dupuis’ face. He drops the pencil he was fiddling with and pushes back chair. Beat. He gets slowly to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: DUPUIS
dialogues.text: 24  (rasps) Get out! Get the hell out of my office!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliette is in a small bar, near the window, watching eve outside and in. At the bar a GUY, who’s good-looking and knows it, talks with another guy and the waitress. Nothing of their conversation filters over, except the oc burst of laughter. Juliette glances over a couple of times, when they laugh particularly loudly. Eventually, the guy notices Juliette, and watches her whi continuing his conversation with the others. After a while, he comes over. Without asking, he takes a Juliette’s table.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: You want my photo? Juliette doesn’t answer.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Have we met?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: I don’t think so.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Why were you staring at me then? what do you want?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Nothing. I wasn’t staring at you.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Bullshit! You keep eying me up. You looking for a man? Juliette smiles, amused by his question. Then, she eyes him up and down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliette lies pensively in bed, the sheets pulled up to h The guy comes out of the bathroom and finishes dressing.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Was it good? Juliette gazes at him before answering.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: No. Not at all. But it’s okay. 25  The guy looks furious. He mumbles something, grabs his jacket and storms out. The camera holds on Juliette, who hasn’t moved an inch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Léa and Juliette walk side by side, chatting. The two little girls run ahead. Wide shot. Then the CAMERA is right behind them. The children are already standing at some animal cages.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: Auntie, look! They’re monkeys. Sometimes they spit at people. They all stop by the monkey cages. Little Lili and Emelia pulls faces.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: It’s not fair locking them up. They haven’t done anything. Prisons are for bad people, not animals? Isn’t that so, Mummy? Eh, Auntie? Léa grabs Little Lili by the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: We’re going!

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: What did I do?

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Nothing, get your sister. We’1l go and buy you some waffles. The two girls race ahead once more.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Don’t be silly. Léa doesn’t answer. They walk along in silence.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Do you think you can erase fifteen years of your life like that? Just by not talking about it? Do you think I was asleep the whole time, like in some kind of fairy tale? Then, one morning, the good fairy Léa came to wake me up? 23. INT. LEA & LUC’S BEDROOM - NIGHT Léa is in bed, reading a book. 26 Léa sits on the edge of the bed, listening to the soccer a transistor radio.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO ANNOUNCER, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Auxerre beat Sochaux 3-2. Lens and Lille drew 2-2 in the big northern derby. Monaco lost to Bordeaux 2-1. Saint-Etienne defeated Marseille 3-0. PSG lost to Nancy at home by 3 goals to 1... Luc Yes! PSG lost! Ha ha! They can stick it up their asses! He flicks off his radio. Luc What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Can’t you see? I’m peeling potatoes. Luc Very funny. Jeez, 3-1! (rubs his hands together) Michel’s gonna be in such a bad mood. Luc lies back and gazes at the ceiling. Luc Are the chicklets asleep?

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: After all the running they did, they were flat out at seven. Luc What about your sister?

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: What about her? Is she asleep, do you mean? Luc No... What did... I don’t know... Do you talk?

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Yes. We talk. Luc Did you ask her...

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: What? 27  Luc You know... Why? Why she did it?

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: (wide-eyed) What the hell is wrong with you? Luc Well, what do you talk about then?

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Sister things. Luc You’re shitting me!

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: What do you expect me to say? It all takes time. It’s not easy. My parents banished any thought of my sister from my head. Now, I’ve got her back. It’s like a re-birth. What happened before is... Oh, just let me sleep! She puts her book down, turns off her light and rolls ove

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Desserts has been served. Around the table are Léa, Luc, Papy Paul, Michel, Juliett another couple - Samir and his younger, pregnant wife, Ka Through the partition doors, we see Little Lili and Emeli on the couches, fully dressed. At table, the atmosphere is upbeat with all the guests la joking happily. Sitting next to Michel, Juliette seems quite relaxed, too still a little reserved. Just like Luc, who occasionally glances apprehensively at The conversation opens 0.S., the time it takes for the ca track past the two kids into the dining room.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: And you know your father backs me 100% on this one. Don’t you, Papy Paul? Luc (0.S.) You must be joking! Dad’s the most loyal supporter Nancy have ever had. Aren’t you, Dad? He reaches for the salad bowl. 28  Léa nods.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Watch out! I glued it back together but I’m not promising anything.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: Katrina?

dialogues.speaker: SAMIR
dialogues.text: Michel, it’s outrageous that you’ve lived in Lorraine for years and you still support a team that’s mostly made up of Brazilians.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: Mostly? Only two Brazilians play for PSG! You don’t know what you’re talking about! Anyway, you’1l bore Juliette!

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Unlikely! I love football. I played a lot when I was a teenager.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Seriously?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: You were too small to remember.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: The perfect woman! Beautiful, intelligent and loves football.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Except for the supporters.

dialogues.speaker: SAMIR
dialogues.text: Take that!

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: Please, Samir, I won’t let an Afghan surgeon paid by al-Qaida to run amok in French hospitals beat me in an argument about football. Luc Can you play on Sunday?

dialogues.speaker: KAISHA
dialogues.text: Forget it. He was saying earlier that he has a zillion exams to mark.

dialogues.speaker: SAMIR
dialogues.text: 29  That’s the third week running you’ve bailed on us.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: Yeah, it’s been three weeks that two hundred papers have been sitting on my desk, waiting for me to mark them.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: You play football together? The camera closes in on Michel and Juliette. OS, the buzz of the others’ conversation. Juliette nods.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: We try. Some days, there’s only ten of us and some days forty people turn up to play, which gets a bit crazy. You should come watch us one day.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Why not.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: Do you like it here?

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: Léa said you lived down south for a long time.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: That’s right.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Carcassonne.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: Right, it’s pretty down there. The Black Mountain and all that. Toulouse not far away...

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Do you come from Paris?

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: Yes, but I got bored of it. I go back as infrequently as possible. Life’s good here. If you can put up with lunkheads like these guys! They smile at each other. 25. INT. LIBRARY, LEA AND LUC’S HOUSE - DAY 30 Juliette quietly enters Papy Paul’s room. He sits in his chair, reading. He looks up and smiles at Juliette.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Can I sit with you a while? She sits in the chair opposite him. Papy Paul goes back to his book. Beat. Juliette begins to talk. Papy Paul smiles at her.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Where I was until recently, I always kept a few books near my pillow. I sensed their presence at night when I turned over. It reassured me. She leans forward to see the title of the book he’s readi by Nerval.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: I read and re-read that one. Not so much as a means of escape but like a dream. 26. INT. INSPECTOR’S OFFICE - DAY Juliette is sitting opposite the Inspector as in the prev scene.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: During the week, I eat canned food mostly - lentils and sausages or beef stew. Those are my favourites. I eat in front of the TV onSometimes, I don’t even heat them up. I can’t cook to save my life and I can’t be bothered to learn. I have some green vegetables at the weekend. Doctor’s orders. Do you agree with him?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Definitely. You can’t just eat tinned food.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: I guess... What about eggs?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: They’re okay, but not every day.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: No, I usually boil or fry one up ona Sunday and eat it in front of the Tv. Do you watch TV? 31

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Not even when you were in prison?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: I see. I thought everybody in prison watched TV. I force myself. It’s a kind of punishment. There’s something totally ugly about it. Like a pile of rubbish that’s delivered to your door. Every evening, I feel like the heap’s bigger and uglier than the day before. And it smacks me in the face. (beat ) How about you? Everything okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliette waits in a hallway. A door opens and students file out. Juliette ventures in. Léa stands on a raised dais, gathering her things togethe talking to a black student dressed in suit and tie.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: We’11 check as soon as we can, Mr. Bamakalé, but I can’t see why the computer would have made a mistake.

dialogues.speaker: BAMAKALE
dialogues.text: It made two last year alone, Miss. And every time, I’m the aggrieved party.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: In any case, the server is down right now, so be patient and stop sending me notes every other day. (sees Juliette) You’11 have to excuse me, I have an appointment. Léa goes over to Juliette.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Am I glad to see you! Let’s get out of here. I thought you were going straight home.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: I wanted to talk. 32

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliette and Léa sit at a table. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: It was a minor intestinal haemorrhage, but they kept him in for tests. He was riddled with cancer. He died two months later.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: When exactly?

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: March 4, 1999. When we found out he had no chance of pulling through, I wanted to tell you. I had a huge fight with Mummy, and she went and told him. He made me promise never to contact you. He was crying. His voice came out in a feeble rasp. He was hooked up to dozens of tubes. He weighed barely more than fifty kilos. I cried, too. And I promised him. I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Did you ever think of us, when you were down there?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Down there? That makes it sound so pretty and nice. “Down there” was a prison. She shows anger for the first time. Awkward silence.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Do you know what a prison is? Hours and days in prison? Years in prison? The outside world leaving you behind. Life leaving you behind. Everything leaving you behind.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: (calmer) Is she still living at Beaufans?

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Mummy? No. I had to find a home for her. She lived with us, at first, then two years after Dad died, she began to lose her memory. Now, she doesn’t recognize anyone. When I go to see her, she thinks I’m a nurse or a neighbour or something. 33

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They never spoke about me? Léa shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: What did they tell other people?

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Anybody who knew the family knew better than to mention it. Anybody else thought I was their only daughter.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: They thought that or they were told that?

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: They were told that?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Who told them? Mum and Dad?

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: And you? Léa doesn’t answer. Tears well in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: They filled my head with it. Beat. Juliette glances round the bar. Changes the subject.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: (lighter) I slept with a guy last week.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: You did what?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: (smiles) I slept with a guy. Léa stops crying. Begins to laugh.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Who? Where?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: A guy I met in a café. We got a room in a hotel. 34

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just like that?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Just like that. They both burst out laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a spare room, piled high with boxes, Juliette and Litt sit side by side at an old piano. Emelia sits on the floo Juliette teaches Little Lili a song (A la Claire Fontaine piano needs tuning.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: No, look! G, G, B, B, A, B, G, G, G, B, B, A, B... Try again. Little Lili plunks out the tune.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: That’s better! Spread your fingers more, like that... Good. And hit the keys harder.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: It’s not easy, Auntie!

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Stop! G, G, B, B, A! You have to change note.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: I’1l never get it right.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Of course, you will! I used to play this with your Mummy, you know.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: with Mummy?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: LILT
dialogues.text: Mummy played the piano? I don’t believe you.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: She used to be very good. This tune was one of our favourites.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: Because it’s called Fontaine like you? 35  Juliette smiles and nods.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: I never saw Mummy play! She won’t let me play piano. She wants me to learn the flute. If she sees us in here, she’1l be so angry!

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: No, she won’t. Don’t worry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A WOMAN sits behind a desk. Juliette sits opposite her. The Woman finishes reading a file and closes it.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: You have all the qualifications for the job. But in this instance, even if it’s just a secretary’s job, I have to refer it to the director of the hospital who will make the final decision. If he approves it, nobody here must ever know that you were a doctor. And especially that you... You know what I mean. Juliette is about to say something.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Don’t thank me, I’m not doing it for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reclining on the couch, with books and notes all around h prepares a lecture. Luc enters with a mug of tea and puts it on the coffee ta Léa thanks him without looking up. Luc goes over to the window. Outside, Juliette walks in t Little Lili is also out there, running all over the place Juliette doesn’t pay her any attention. Luc You wouldn’t guess, looking at her.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: (miles away) What? Luc She looks totally normal. Léa perks up suddenly, glances out the window, then at Lu 36

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop it! Luc What? Maybe you’d prefer to forget what she did, but I can’t!

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Leave her alone!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A big, oval swimming pool. Juliette and Léa float next to each other, arms and legs outstretched.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: What did you want to do?

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Me? I couldn’t have become a doctor like you. They would have freaked, but there was never any chance of that. I was always more attracted to literature and languages. The day I told them, I could see the relief on their faces. (beat ) The water’s great, isn’t it? Juliette smiles and nods.

dialogues.speaker: MONSIEUR LUCIEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hello there, Léa! The camera pulls back to reveal MONSIEUR LUCIEN, a paunch old, with a Clark Gable moustache, gold chain and signet a spray-on tan.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Hi, Monsieur Lucien. How are you?

dialogues.speaker: MONSIEUR LUCIEN
dialogues.text: Very well. Aren’t you going to introduce me?

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Of course. This is my sister Juliette. (to Juliette) Monsieur Lucien’s a regular here.

dialogues.speaker: MONSIEUR LUCIEN
dialogues.text: Your sister? I see. Hello!

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: 37  That’s right, my sister. She’s off limits, Monsieur Lucien! He chuckles and walks on.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: He comes down here to try to chat up women. He’11 hit on anyone, young or old.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Does he ever get anywhere?

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: You’d be surprised! Léa glances at Juliette as she floats in the water, eyes She reaches out her hand and brushes her fingers over a s on Juliette’s thigh.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: I was running to you for a hug. I jumped up and you tripped over a branch. I can still see the blood pouring from the wound and your face going deathly white... I thought you were going to die, all because of me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luc sits with his two daughters. He hands Emelia a yoghurt, then goes back to reading the pages of the paper. Little Lili is on Papy Paul’s lap, also eating yoghurt.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: When’s Mummy coming home? Luc I don’t know. Soon.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: And Auntie? Luc I’ve no idea.

dialogues.speaker: LILT
dialogues.text: Are they together?

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: I haven’t a clue. Eat up! Beat.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: 38  Doesn’t Auntie Juliette have a job? Luc Why’d you ask?

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: No reason. I just thought she must have a job because she’s pretty old now. Luc has his nose in the paper.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: Well? What’s her job? Luc You ask her, smarty-pants. Can’t you see I’m trying to do some work? 34, INT. JULIETTE’S ROOM - EVENING In the darkness, Juliette watches the rain falling on the garden. There are papers scattered on her bed, and what looks to photograph. 35. INT. SOCIAL WORKER’S OFFICE - DAY

dialogues.speaker: SOCIAL WORKER
dialogues.text: Well, that just about covers everything. Come back and see me ina few weeks. Meanwhile, I’11 call the hospital to see what’s happening. It would be the perfect job for you. I’11 be in touch. She walks to the door with Juliette. Takes out a cigarette. Offers one to Juliette as they go the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: No, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: SOCIAL WORKER
dialogues.text: I was wondering... I read your file and the notes on your trial... You never said a word throughout the investigation and the trial. why? No answer.

dialogues.speaker: SOCIAL WORKER
dialogues.text: You even refused to talk to the psychologists. Their report runs to two lines. Something about a lethal injection “foreshadowing the choice of silence”. I don’t really get that. 39

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (furious) And you think I’m going to talk to you now? She storms off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Léa and Luc walk arm in arm down the road. Luc It’s been ages since you dropped by the lab to pick me up.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Did you miss it? Luc Yeah, I like it when you surprise me.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: How about a movie and then dinner? Luc Sure.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Is there anything you really want to see? There’s a Kurosawa retrospective at the Cameo. Luc No way! Japanese films always put me to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Well, they’re probably still showing The Shop Around The Corner. Luc Good idea. I haven’t seen that in so long! But that means we’1l be back really late, if you want to go for dinner afterwards.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: It’1l be fine. Beat. Luc Are you sure Katrina doesn’t mind?

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: What’s Katrina got to do with anything? 40  Luc She’s looking after the girls, isn’t she?

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: No, I asked Juliette. Luc You asked your sister to look after our daughters? Have you lost your mind? She killed her kid, remember! That’s insane! 37. EXT/INT. LUC & LEA’S HOUSE - EVENING Luc screeches to a halt outside the house. He leaps out of the car, races up the path and into the h Luc (heart pounding) Lili? Emelia? Lili!!! Juliette rushes out of the living room with a book in her Luc (barks) Where are my daughters? Where are they?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Upstairs. They’re asleep. We had dinner early and they were tired, SO... Before she can finish, Luc dashes upstairs. Juliette is stunned. Léa arrives.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: You’re back already? What’s wrong with Luc? Léa looks awkwardly at her sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliette strolls through the empty museum. She stops in her tracks when she comes to a large ultra - painting of a woman in mourning about to throw herself in at the bottom of which lies a coffin. Other women hold her back. Men in dark suits and top hats stand in the background.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It’s called Grief. 41  Juliette is startled.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: You startled me.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: Hi. (beat ) Impressive, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Who painted it?

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: Emile Friant. Famous when he was alive, totally forgotten since his death in the 1930s. I’1l show you another of his that is my favourite. Come on... They walk into the next room. Michel stops at a small painting showing a young woman’s against a snowy landscape.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: The first time, I saw it, it blew me away. She looks exactly like a girl I was in love with in my early 20s. I was crazy about her. She didn’t even see me, though. This is my revenge. She’s imprisoned in a frame and I can look at her whenever I want. She can’t say a thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliette and Michel are having lunch.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: Léa is amazing. She’s one of the best specialists in France in her field. But she doesn’t have the killer instinct. In our work, you have to trample over people to get ahead.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Do you have that killer instinct?

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: Do I look like I do?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: I don’t know you well enough.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: No. I’m not into that anymore. 42

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were? What changed?

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: Nothing. Everything. Life. Life changes us. Léa told me you’re looking for a job.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Yes, I had an interview for a secretary’s job at the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: Secretary? That’s what you do?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Yes. I mean, no. It’s complicated.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: (smiles) In that case, I’11 shut up. (raises his glass) To you!

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: To the girl in the museum!

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: Christ, no! They laugh.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. CAR/RETIREMENT HOME
dialogues.text: Léa parks her car.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: No, I’d rather not. I’11 wait here for you. Léa grabs a bouquet of flowers off the backseat.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: I won’t be long. She gets out. Sitting in the car, Juliette glances up at the windows of building that Léa entered. Eventually, she gets out of the car, paces up and down th pavement, stops, leans against the car. In the garden of the retirement home, old people sit quie benches. 43 Suddenly, Léa appears at one of the windows, opening the An old lady is standing next to her with her back to the ANGLE on Juliette. Her eyes fill with tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliette enters. Glances round the café. The Inspector gets up and waves to her. Juliette goes over. They sit down.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: You don’t mind that I suggested we meet here? I’m sick of my office.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: No, I like cafés. It’s one of the things I missed most when I was in prison. The noise, the atmosphere, the smoke and the buzz of conversations. The Inspector notices she has wet hair.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Is it raining?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: No, I’ve been swimming.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: You swim? Me, too, but not in swimming pools. I told you about the Orinoco, didn’t 1?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Yes, the first time we met.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: It’s a huge, huge river. Over 1,500 Miles long. It never ends. And it’s powerful. Rapids, waterfalls, flood plains...

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: You’ve seen it for real?

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Not yet. It’s a project of mine. We’1l see. It’s not easy. I have a young daughter. She lives with her mother and I don’t see her often. Her mother moved away. And my daughter has moved away from me, too. You know, the Orinoco is a real mystery. Several expeditions have set  out to find its source and none of them has ever really succeeded. They found little streams, but not the real source. It’s fascinating, isn’t it? We know everything nowadays, but we can’t find the source of a river. (beat) I signed and approved the papers.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Sorry?

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: For the job at the hospital. They asked for my opinion.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: No problem. (the waiter arrives) What will you have?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family dinner is over. Papy Paul leaves the table. Juliette begins washing up. Little Lili is finishing her dessert. Léa isn’t there. Luc Lili, when you finish, brush your teeth and straight to bed. Don’t wake your sister.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: When’s Mummy coming home? Luc After her meeting.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: Late? Luc I expect so. Go on, I’1l come up and give you a kiss. Little Lili hurries out. Luc and Juliette are alone. Luc seems ill at ease. Juliette keeps on washing up. Luc How did it go at the bank? 45

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They let me open an account, but they won’t give me a chequebook until I get a job. Luc Any news from the hospital?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Not a word. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Don’t worry, Luc, I won’t bother you much longer. I’11 find something else. Luc (feebly) I never meant for you to think -

dialogues.speaker: LILI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I want a story! Luc (gratefully) Coming right up, sweetheart. He exits. Juliette wipes the table. Luc reappears, displeased. Luc She wants you to read her a story. 43. INT. LITTLE LILI’S BEDROOM - NIGHT Juliette sits on the bed, reading. Little Lili is fast asleep.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: “The old man smiled and for a Moment, it seemed to Baji that his host was a boy of his own age, or a young girl, or an infant. In the sky, the silver stars twinkled and the moon rose, as full as a woman’s tummy...” Juliette realizes that Little Lili is asleep. She quietly closes the book. And gazes at the child. Impassively. Eerily. Eventually, she leans forward and kisses Little Lili with emotion for the first time. 46  In the doorway, Léa watches. Juliette turns round and sees her. Léa smiles at her sister. 44, EXT. OUTSIDE LEA’S HOUSE - DAY Luc loads up the car. The kids are already strapped in th backseat. Léa brings out sleeping bags, food and plates. Juliette helps them. They all seem excited to be going away.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Did you bring a sweater? It can get cold out there.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Right, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliette comes downstairs with a sweater in one hand. Before leaving, she stops by Papy Paul’s room. He is sitting in a chair, reading as ever.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Will you be okay? You have everything you need? (beat ) We’1l be back tomorrow. Goodbye!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family sings happily as they drive along.

The car pulls up outside a rundown farmhouse. The duck pond. Adults and children playing. More friends arrive. In all, there are over fifteen adult including Michel, and Samir and his wife. Children bouncing around in the bedrooms. Women busy in the kitchen. Men opening bottles of wine. Playing soccer. The table set for dinner. MONTAGE ends. 47

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An open fire blazes in the hearth. Children are fast asleep, curled up on the floor or in ch In one corner, the older children play a game. Around the table, the adults have flushed faces. Empty bottles litter the table. A joint goes round. Everybody’s laughing and joking. One guy (GERARD) looks particularly drunk.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: I don’t have to like Rohmer! It’s a free country.

dialogues.speaker: GERARD
dialogues.text: I don’t see how you can teach literature and not understand Rohmer’s movies.

dialogues.speaker: SAMIR
dialogues.text: Léa didn’t say she doesn’t underst and them. She said she doesn’t like them. There’s a subtle difference.

dialogues.speaker: GERARD
dialogues.text: I can’t believe what I’m hearing! I can’t help wondering how you explain Racine to your students!

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: That’s irrelevant. What’s Racine got to do with anything?

dialogues.speaker: GERARD
dialogues.text: Rohmer is the Racine of the 20" century, but if you guys are too stupid to see it...

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: That’s totally unfair.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: (hands Gerard the joint) Here, have some of this and chill out. Next, you’1l be telling us that Stallone is Shakespeare.

dialogues.speaker: GERARD
dialogues.text: Screw you! You don’t care about anything except soccer. What about you, Juliette? what do you think? Her face cupped in her hands, Juliette smiles and shrugs. 48

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliette doesn’t think anything. Juliette watches and judges. But who is Juliette? A woman of mystery. A sprite, a goblin... Having been hidden from us all this time, Juliette - Luc Cut it out! You’re a pain in the ass. Go get some fresh air Gerard raps his knife against his glass.

dialogues.speaker: GERARD
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, pray silence! I would humbly like to suggest we play a little game. The winner will receive my deepest consideration...

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: You can shove your consideration!

dialogues.speaker: GERARD
dialogues.text: And a kiss from Juliette.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Gerard, you can be such an asshole!

dialogues.speaker: GERARD
dialogues.text: The game is to find the reason why Léa hid her delightful sister from us for the last two hundred years. Where was Juliette? What was Juliette doing?

dialogues.speaker: SAMIR
dialogues.text: Knock it off!

dialogues.speaker: GERARD
dialogues.text: Was Juliette on the other side of the world? Was she not speaking to Léa? Was Juliette...

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: Cut it out, Gerard.

dialogues.speaker: GERARD
dialogues.text: ...hidden somewhere in Switzerland? In a convent? Was Juliette... Luc You’re getting on everybody’s nerves

dialogues.speaker: GERARD
dialogues.text: . a lion tamer in a circus, a Mossad spy, an amnesic? Answer us, Juliette! Answer us! 49  He gazes at her.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Shut the fuck up, Gerard! Luc Be quiet, or I’1l belt you!

dialogues.speaker: GERARD
dialogues.text: Let Juliette speak! For once, I have a heroine from a novel in front of me, I want to hear her tell me...

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: That you’re an asshole!

dialogues.speaker: GERARD
dialogues.text: The truth! Juliette disappears. Juliette reappears. Juliette? Juliette?

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Go to bed!

dialogues.speaker: GERARD
dialogues.text: Not before I know where Juliette has been. The beautiful Juliette! Juliette! Juliette! Gradually, everybody else falls silent. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: (deadpan) I was in prison. Fifteen years. I killed my son. Suddenly, Gerard bursts out laughing. Everybody else joins in, except Léa, Luc and Michel.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: That’11 teach you, Gerard!

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Well done, Juliette!

dialogues.speaker: SAMIR
dialogues.text: What do you have to say now, loudmouth?

dialogues.speaker: GERARD
dialogues.text: Okay, she wins. I give up. The atmosphere lightens again. Juliette discreetly ups and leaves. Léa and Luc glance at each other. 50

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliette stands by the lake. It’s a very dark night. 0.S., laughter filters from the farmhouse. Then, footsteps. Michel draws level with Juliette. Puts a hand on her shou She shrugs it off.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: Sorry about him. He’s an ass when he’s drunk, but he’s a good guy. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: They all think you were joking. I... (pause) I’m sure you weren’t. Before I got my job at the university, I taught in prisons for ten years. I rarely talk about it... I used to go in three times a week. And I’d come out three times a week. That changed my whole life, my whole way of looking at things, people, the sky, passing time, coming and going, being in the street, everything. I stopped being so certain of things, making judgments the way people always do. Everybody I met behind bars, it seemed like they were just like me. They could have been me and I could have been them. It’s a fine line sometimes. 50. EXT. OUTSIDE LEA’S HOUSE - NIGHT Michel parks outside the house. Juliette is in the passenger seat.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: Will you be okay?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Yes. Thanks for the ride. They gaze at each other. Michel reaches out to caress her cheek.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Don’t... Please... I’m still... a long way away. She gets out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Léa leads a discussion with a dozen students. She’s tense, irritable. 51 The STUDENT she is debating with is very calm and measur As their argument develops, the other students glance at with raised eyebrows.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: That’s only true of Raskolnikov! You can’t extend the notion of redemptive guilt to humanity in general and suggest that each murder contains its own redemption.

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT
dialogues.text: Yet the aim of the novelist is to reconstitute the world. Dostoyevsky is no exception.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: In the case of this novel, you know full well that the narration is impersonal and, moreover, incomplete, as if the author refused to put forward a single worldview because he knows that there are numerous interpretations and motivations. And numerous shades of truth.

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT
dialogues.text: But the first draft is in the first person. One can deduce, therefore, that the initial project was indeed to portray a single soul that might give the reader an intimate yet universal insight into murder and murderers. Léa is really wound up. Her students are shocked. Stunned silence.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: You don’t know what you’re talking about! What do you know about murder and murderers!

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: And what did Dostoyevsky know about it deep down? Well? Nothing! Nada! Zilch! Even masterpieces are no more than hypotheses, simplistic extrapolations that are nothing compared to true life. Nothing. Got that? If you stopped thinking a book is the last word on something, you wouldn’t spout so much bullshit! Léa pulls herself together. 52

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... I am terribly sorry. I apologize. I don’t know what... She grabs her notes and hurries out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Léa rushes down a hallway. When she reaches her office, she finds Bamakalé sitting o outside. He is impeccably dressed as always. As soon as he sees her, he jumps to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: BAMAKALE
dialogues.text: Good morning, I wondered if I -

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Not now! This is not the time! She rushes into her office and slams the door. Bamakalé stares at it in dismay. 53. INT. LEA’S OFFICE - DAY Holding her head in her hands, Léa sobs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliette follows the woman who interviewed her for the jo She introduces Juliette to a couple of other secretaries, away at their computers. They come to an empty desk.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: This is your desk. Your job is essentially to type up medical reports and perhaps help out your colleagues from time to time. The trial period is three weeks. At the end of that period, the director will inform you of his decision. I’11 let you get settled in. She walks away, stops and backtracks.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: I rely on you to be discreet, of course. 55. INT. LEA’S HOUSE - DAY Léa arrives home. Dumps grocery bags in the hall. Listens 0.S., on the piano, the tune Juliette taught Little Lili earlier scene. It clearly perturbs Léa. 53 She hurries upstairs to the spare room where Little Lili with Juliette next to her. Emelia sits on the floor. Papy Paul is in one corner, smi Little Lili stops and runs over to hug her mother.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: Mummy! Come and play! Play, Mummy! Auntie said you used to be very good! Léa hesitates. Juliette shuffles over on the piano stool, and nods to he down. Léa still hesitates. Then goes over and sits at the piano Each movement seems deeply thought -out. She gazes at the piano like a long-lost friend. Then her sister. They begin playing together. Juliette starts to sing.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: A la claire fontaine m’en allant promener J’ai trouvé l’eau si claire Que je m’y suis baignée.. (At the fountain as I was walking by The water was so clear That I want for a swim...) Léa joins in.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Il y a longtemps que je t’aime jamais je ne t’oublierai.. (I’ve loved you so long I can never forget you...) J’ai trouvé l’eau si claire Que je m’y suis baignée.. A la feuille d’un chéne Je me suis essuyée (The water was so clear That I want for a swim I found an oak leaf to use to dry myself) Il y a longtemps que je t’aime jamais je ne t’oublierai.. (I’ve loved you so long I can never forget you...) 54  Lalala lalala lalalalalala Lalala lalalala Lalala lalala lalalalalala.. The children applaud. Papy Paul looks delighted. The girls hug their mother and kiss her. Léa and Juliette glance at each other, deeply moved. Juliette runs her hand down Léa’s arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A headset in her ears, Juliette types up a report. Three young male DOCTORS walk over. One of them lobs a tape onto Juliette’s desk.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Type that and send it over to Cardiology. Juliette removes her headset.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Sorry?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: (irritably) I said, type that now and send it over to Cardio.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: The report I’m typing is urgent, as well.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Who the hell do you think you are? You’re just a secretary. Do what I say. I want that over there in fifteen minutes. Got it?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Fine. They walk away.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: (mutters to his colleagues ) They’re hiring them older than before and more stupid than ever!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Inspector and Juliette sit at a table.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: 55  At my age, it’s not easy meeting someone new. I don’t like going out. And being a cop scares people off. But I could be at Social Services, it’d be the same. I sit at a desk all day and process paperwork. I’d be no use trying to catch a thief! (beat ) This is where I met my wife. They’ve redecorated, but it’s basically still the same. Where did you meet your husband?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: At college.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: He was a doctor, too?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: No, he dropped out after two years. He got a job supervising a team of health visitors.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: When did you last see him?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: At the trial. He testified against me.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Like my wife. Ever since, she’s never... She sends my daughter here by plane or train with a label round her neck like a parcel. (beat ) I could still describe exactly how she was dressed the first time we met. (beat ) How’s work?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Nobody giving you any trouble?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: No...

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: By the way, I think I’1l soon be... You remember my Orinoco project... After all this time, it’s much clearer in my mind now. Deep down, there’s 56  nothing and nobody to make it worth me staying here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliette sits with Emelia on her lap, flicking through a book, pointing to a picture and saying the word out loud times. Emelia tries to repeat the words. Suddenly, there’s a loud crash upstairs, followed by scre 59. INT. LEA & LUC’S BEDROOM - EVENING Luc writhes in pain on the floor, clutching his shoulder. Nearby, scattered tools and a stepladder lying on its sid

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: You idiot! Luc Will you shut up? It hurts. Little Lili pokes her head round the door.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: Daddy! what happened? Juliette rushes in, with Emelia in her arms. She puts Emelia down and kneels next to Luc. All her doctor’s reflexes come flooding back.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Where does it hurt? Luc My shoulder. Juliette begins examining him. Papy Paul peeks in.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: I told you to leave it! You’re no good with a hammer.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: It’s okay. Dislocated, that’s all. I’1l put it back. It’1l hurt but once it’s in, that’s it. Juliette manipulates his shoulder with great assurance. Little Lili watches, wide-eyed. Luc Ouch!

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: Daddy! 57

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Feel better? Luc flexes his shoulder. Luc Yes... Yes... lots. Thanks, Juliette. Papy Paul ducks out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Next time, remember you’re useless at DIY.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: Where’d you learn to do that, Auntie? Juliette, Léa and Luc glance at each other.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: On TV! You learn all kinds of useful things watching TV!

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: See, Mummy, the TV’s not “inane”, like you always say it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliette and Léa hold onto the side, kicking their legs.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: With the kids, it’s hard to keep up my research. I go to less conferences, I publish less... But I like working here. I get on with my colleagues. Michel, for example, is the kind of guy who’1l never let you down.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Has he always been single?

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: No... I don’t think so. Actually, I don’t know. He’s actually pretty secretive. (beat ) I don’t believe it! Check that out! Look who Monsieur Lucien has on his arm. Paunchy Monsieur Lucien struts along in the company of a 25-year-old. He winks at Juliette and Léa.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: That’s wild! There’s always hope when you’re a guy. 58

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Had you forgotten me?

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: You forgot me all those years, didn’t you? Léa gazes intensely at her sister. 61. INT. LEA’S HOME OFFICE - DAY Léa places a heavy box on the desk, under Juliette’s nose

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Open it. Juliette hesitates, then opens the box. It’s full of diaries.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Take one out. It doesn’t matter which. Juliette reaches in and pulls out a diary.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Open it at any page. Juliette opens the diary. Under each date, Juliette’s name is handwritten, followed number: Juliette 918, Juliette 919... Juliette takes out another diary. Same thing: Juliette 31 Juliette 3128...

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: That was the first thing I did every morning. Write your name and the number of days you’d been gone. (beat ) I suppose you could say it only took a second and it was just a few letters and figures, but I thought about you so hard in those few moments every day. Every morning, we were reunited.

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Yes... Good morning, sir... Yes... I’1l be right there. 63. INT. DIRECTOR’S OFFICE - DAY 59 The DIRECTOR stands glancing out the window, as if to av Juliette’s eyes. She sits facing him. On his desk, framed photos of his wife, four children, th two horses...

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: Does that mean I’m out of a job?

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: Of course not! I didn’t say that, did I? Just don’t forget you’re on trial. Make an effort. That’s all I’m saying. Try to be less... withdrawn. Open up a bit. (beat ) Of course, I understand that it’s not... I mean, I understand but...

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: What do you understand? The Director has no answer. 64. Léa Léa She Léa and Léa INT. EMELIA & LITTLE LILI’S ROOMS - NIGHT tucks Emelia in. She is already asleep. kisses her, turns on a nightlight and slips out. goes into Little Lili’s room and finds her daughter readi

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Okay, Little Lili, lights out now. closes the book, puts it on the nightstand, kisses her da is about to turn out the light...

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: No, please! Leave it on!

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: 60  When you and Auntie Juliette were little, did you spend a lot of time together?

I thought it was a mistake. It was the first time ever. There was a young woman waiting to see me. She smiled. It was Léa. I listened to her without saying a word. She promised she’d come again. dialogues.text: I knew as soon as the first symptoms appeared. I hardly even read the results of the tests. Pierrot grabbed the letter and started writing a poem on it. When he gave it back, he was beaming with pride. My little boy... (beat ) I saw him looking at me, so happy, so beautiful. He was my Pierrot. Then, I pictured the little corpse he was going to become.

They are reaching the conclusion of a long, painful discu

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: I could picture him at every stage of the disease. I knew exactly how it would develop. The worst thing was that I knew he wouldn’t just fall asleep and never wake up, like ina kiddies’ story. Soon, he wouldn’t be 82  able to move. He would suffer and gradually the life would be squeezed out of him. And there was no cure. Nothing to relieve his suffering. (beat ) I went away with him. People said I abducted him. I suppose I did. I ran away with him. I fled with him and I fed him and I showed him all the places I loved best... Saint - Hippolyte, Beaulian, the Palioure coast... I had to increase the dose of painkillers almost every day. He was so brave. He used to say to me, “I’m your little husband...” (beat ) One evening, we had a little party, just the two of us. It was in the Green House. We sang, we laughed and I read him all his favourite stories. Then, I put him to bed. I told him I loved him, that he was running a fever and I had to give him a jab. He gave me a hug and held me as tight as his little arms could. He recited his poem and I held him in my arms until morning. (beat ) Afterwards, nothing seemed important anymore.

dialogues.speaker: LEA
dialogues.text: Why didn’t you say...

dialogues.speaker: JULIETTE
dialogues.text: I felt so alone. So alone. Anyway, there was nothing to say. Trying to explain it would be trying to excuse it. Death has no excuses. One way or another, I was guilty. I had brought a child into the world only to sentence him to death. (beat ) You know, the most horrible prison... The worst prison is the death of your child. There is never any release from that prison. Léa holds Juliette in her arms. Juliette clings to her sister. Léa gives her a kiss.
